sense.name: a sudden, brief burst of light
sense.examples: We were surrounded by lightening flashes and big waves during the storm at sea. The thermonuclear flash lit up the sky like a false dawn. The grenade exploded with a yellow flash of light.

sense.name: a sudden perceptual sensation
sense.commentary: FLASH[+state][+perceptual][+sensation][+sudden] Note: an immediate physiological or emotional response to stimulus.
sense.examples: He felt a flash of pain in his foot. A flash of anger shot through her when she remembered his insulting comment.

sense.name: a sudden, vivid mental insight
sense.commentary: FLASH[+state][+mental][+insight][+sudden] Note: involves cognition, reasoning - not pure sensation (Sense 2)
sense.examples: In a flash of insight John saw the proof to the mathematical puzzle. Reversing the sequence of those scenes in the play was a flash of inspiration.

sense.name: a moment of time, a split second
sense.examples: Mary said she'd be back in a flash. Quick as a flash the cat had captured the ball of yarn between its paws.

sense.name: an ostentatious, eye-catching manner
sense.examples: John likes to date girls who have a lot of flash. Their presentation had flash but not much substance.

sense.name: communication signal using pulses of light
sense.commentary: FLASH[+event][+speech_act][+signal][+with_light_pulses] Note: implies the presence of Sense 1, but is an intentional series of these.
sense.examples: Sally signaled the all-clear by a series of short and long flashes with her flashlight. The yellow flash ahead indicates caution.

sense.name: a bulletin of headline news
sense.examples: We heard the news flash about the assassination of the dictator. The radio station provides the latest news flashes every hour on the hour.

sense.name: an eye-catching patch of color or form
sense.examples: The flash of blue in the tree was the wing of a kingfisher. The slit in her skirt revealed a flash of thigh as she walked down the street. The maple trees in early September had a few flashes of red on their leaves.

sense.name: camera attachment that provides momentary light during picture taking
sense.examples: Did the flash go off when John took the picture? She set her camera to a wide aperture to avoid using the flash.

sense.name: excess substance protruding from between the joined surfaces of a mold
sense.examples: Flash appears on the part's edge where the mold has metal meeting metal. Inadequate mold support can also lead to flash. In multi-cavity molds, flash is often caused by an improper balance of melt flow.

sense.name: a brief, non-repeating success
sense.commentary: Idiom: flash_in_the_pan Note: the expression comes from the situation where a flintlock weapon's priming powder ignited in the gunlock pan without resulting in the ignition of the main charge in the gun's chamber.
sense.examples: Our team's winning streak at the start was just a flash in the pan. The pop singer's success with one single turned out to be a flash in the pan.
